content.description: Start laybacking two side-pulls. Climb the face left of Slip n' Slide. Top out.
Start with two left facing edges. Climb the face left of Trip & Tumble to a top out.
Start with a low edge. Climb the slab keeping left of Discrepancy Clause. Top out.

Straight up the large crack to the prominent overhanging "nose" of the arete. For those with height advantage find a sharp jug to pull the overhang and away up the arete. Others will have to use guile and veer left to attack from a stemming approach. Probably the best route on the cliff.
content.protection: Bolts at the top for TR
content.location: Easily identifiable as the "nose-shaped" dihedral is the most prominent feature on the cliff.

content.description: Start with a tricky mantle in the center of the cliff and then proceed straight up to the overhang right of Last Thoughts on Woody Guthrie. Once standing above the overhang you can continue following your rope line straight up through fingertip slab climbing or bail left before angling back right to the anchors above you.
content.protection: Bolts at the top for TR
content.location: Start is a mantle move and then straight up from there.

content.description: Inward leaning, easy moves. Stay right from the overhang and follow the easy crack line up. The name Frosted Flake is what the developer Ryan Eddingfield remembered. In the Marengo Creek Bluff guide it goes as The Joint.
content.protection: Two bolts at the top for TR
content.location: Rightmost route with easy and obvious start.

content.description: Start as for the traverse, but after exit through the blank face in the center of the outcrop.
content.location: Right side of the first boulder encountered along the trail to the top of Bob's Rock.

content.description: Plug cams up the diagonal and when it runs out, cruise on up to the top. While not listed on the PDF guide, someone has certainly lead it before and the name is speculation based on conversation with an original route developer.Please note, this route would not TR well. Trad only
content.protection: Standard trad rack. Some placements are buried in the crack and would benefit from slings. Would recommend one or two larger cams in the #4-6 range.
content.location: Start at the base of Woody Guthrie

content.description: Climb up to the inverted triangle and then follow the finger crack up to the ledge. Avoid using the arete. Rated 5.9+ in the Marengo Creek Guide, but the current generation of Northland College climbers give it a 10 rating. The guide also references the Daisy Duke variation which is to bail left a few feet when you hit the finger crack. The climbing is easy on this variation.
Stand-start with an edge and small undercling. Climb the slab to an exciting crux on a slopey ledge before running up positive edges to the top.
content.location: Right side of the slab off the hilly section trail to the top of Bob's Rock

content.description: Stand start with an small edges in the center of the face. Climb more slopey crimps up the face to a dirty top out.
content.location: Between the Slabs and Bob's Traverse

content.description: SDS matched on the furthest right rail. Traverse right along similar features for 8' or so until it's possible to make vertical progress with a few slopey crimps before gaining the lip and mantling.Â
content.location: Right side of the first boulder encountered along the trail to the top of Bob's Rock

content.description: Start as for the traverse, but after reaching the second slot, go big for the slopey lip and mantle to top out.
content.location: Right side of the first boulder encountered along the trail to the top of Bob's Rock.

content.description: SDS with hands on two edges. Climb the featured dihedral to a mellow top out. A nice introductory climb.
content.location: Far left side of the first boulder encountered along the trail to the top of Bob's RockÂ

content.description: Start with blocky side-pulls on the right side of the outcrop. Layback similar features before squaring up to the face and finishing up the slab.

Bob's Rock a.k.a Marengo Creek Bluff is a red granite slab leftover from the ancient Penokee Mountain Range. Millions of years of erosion and glaciers have left the scenic hills that border the southern end of the Marengo Valley and stretch over to the U.P.. Bob's is on the Southeast side of the Marengo River and across the valley from the Old Swedish Settlement trail. It is almost visible from Juniper Rock Outlook. Rumors exist about climbing other cliffs in the valley although none of the other faces have ever been developed. The cliff face is approx. 70 feet tall with some easy to moderate climbing. There are currently four pairs of bolts for TR anchors with an access trail that locals sometimes hike for the view. Locals will also frequent the area scavenging for wild ramps when they are in season and occasionally the parking area will be shared with local fishermen.The earliest ascents claimed at the crag were by Burton Lindquist in the 70s and 80s. The bluff was rediscovered in the late 90s. In 1997 Ryan Eddingfield, a Northland College student at the time scouted the cliff and spent the summer cleaning the face and developing the access trail. Ryan first introduced the name Bob Rock and now it goes by Bob's Rock, or Marengo Creek Bluff. Northland College has been using the bluff for outdoor classes ever since and in 2001 student John J. Roeder developed a short guidebook titled Marengo Creek Bluff as part of a class assignment. The college still has a PDF copy. There appear to be 6-7 original routes established in the summer of 97 although their exact locations and names are a matter of some discrepancy and guess work over the years.EMERGENCY:Â Phone service is terrible to non-existent so plan accordingly. First responders will be local volunteer firefighters and EMTs. The closest hospital is Memorial Medical Center in Ashland.EATS: If you're looking for local fare the Four Corners Saloon is located North at the intersection of Four Corners Store Road and County Hwy E. The food is phenomenal and the drinks are well poured. Friday fish fry and ribs night (I believe on Wednesdays) are not to be missed. The atmosphere draws a pleasant crowd and is one of the few establishments where the local hippy and redneck communities come together. If you're headed South you could try the Lakewoods Resort on Namekagon Lake. The closest bar is the Pioneer on County Hwy D and always promises an affordable buzz.
